The essoinee is given a period of a year and a day for his sickness3 at the end of that time he must appear. But how is the year to be reckoned3 in particular what is to be done about leap year? Bracton argues this question at length in a very curious passage⁶. The point, he admits, is disputed, but his own opinion is that in every case a year for this purpose means 365 days and 6 hours, so that the essoinee will always have precisely the same space of time no matter whether a aoth of February occurs or n0.
